questions.text: A 29 year old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation has been in labour for the past 12 hours. She has reached full cervical dilation, but after 2 hours of pushing, she expresses significant fatigue and is unable to continue effectively. On examination, the fetal head is at 0 station, and the maternal and fetal vital signs are stable. All of the following are indications for trial of instrumental delivery except?

choices.text: Fetal distress and fetal head at +2 station
Prolonged second stage of labour fetal head at +3 station

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mentoposterior position

 

Explanation:

Mentoposterior (face) presentation is a contraindication for instrumental delivery, as it complicates vaginal birth, making cesarean section the preferred method.

 

Trial of Instrumental Delivery

Indications

Contraindications
  • Fetal head at +2 station or below, along with
    • Maternal exhaustion
    • Prolonged second-stage labour (Option C)
    • Nonreassuring fetal heart rates and premature placental separation. (Option B)
 
  • Maternal reasons for Operative Vaginal Delivery involve conditions that limit effective pushing or require rapid delivery, such as
    • Severe pulmonary hypertension (Option D)
    • Infections,
    • Neurological diseases, and
    • Serious cardiac disorders.
  • Mentoposterior position 
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Intrauterine death
  • Bony deformities of the fetus, such as osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Coagulopathy in the fetus.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida has been in the second stage of labour for 2 hours. The fetal heart rate shows moderate variability with occasional late decelerations. The doctor is considering forceps or vacuum assistance to expedite delivery. Which of the following is NOT a prerequisite for both forceps and vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Administration of epidural anaesthesia

 

Explanation:

Epidural anaesthesia is not a prerequisite for either forceps or vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. While it can relieve pain and make the procedure more comfortable for the mother, it is not essential.

Pre-Requisites For Forceps Delivery

Maternal Pre-Requisites

Fetal Pre-Requisites
  • Completely dilated cervix (Option A)
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is not suspected
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes (Option B)
  • Informed consent completed
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Willingness to abandon operative vaginal delivery (OVD) if necessary
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • Engaged fetal head (Option C)
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • Vertex presentation
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Known fetal head position
  • Estimated fetal weight

questions.text:
Match the following images of forceps with their names.


	
		
			
			1.

			
			
			
			a. Simpson forceps
			
		
		
			
			2.

			
			
			
			b. Piper forceps
			
		
		
			
			3.

			
			
			
			c. Wrigley's forceps
			
		
		
			
			4.​​​​​​​

			
			
			
			d. Kielland forceps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida is in the second stage of labour. The fetal head is at +2 station, and the obstetrician decides to perform an assisted vaginal delivery using forceps. Which of the following is true regarding the application criteria and initial direction of pull for this forceps delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Low forceps delivery; downward pull.

 

Explanation:

Aspects

Low Forceps Delivery

Outlet Forceps Delivery

Criteria

Fetal head engaged, leading point at station +2 cm or lower.
  • Fetal scalp visible at introitus.
  • Skull at pelvic floor.
  • Sagittal suture in anteroposterior or occiput position.
  • Head at or on the perineum.

Initial Direction of Pull

Downward towards the floor.

Horizontal or slightly upward.

Progressive Pull

Follows birth canal curve downward.

Changes to upward as the head delivers

questions.text: A 32 year old G2P1 is in the second stage of labour. After 2 hours of pushing, the obstetrician performs a vacuum-assisted delivery. The fetal head is at +2 station in the left occiput anterior position. Which type of vacuum cup would be most appropriate for this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Silastic cup

Explanation:

In this scenario, a soft Silastic cup would be appropriate and likely effective with the fetal head at +2 station in the left occiput anterior position.

Silastic (Soft) Cup:

  • Generally preferred for most vacuum-assisted deliveries due to their:
    • Flexibility, which allows for easier application.
    • Lower risk of fetal scalp injuries compared to rigid cups.
    • Effectiveness in most situations, including the one described in the question.
    • Suitable for both occiput anterior and posterior positions.

Malmström (metal) cup (Option B) is a rigid metal cup that offers strong traction but is mainly used in difficult extractions or after failed soft cup attempts due to a higher risk of fetal scalp injuries.

Bird (anterior) cup (Option C) is designed specifically for anterior positions, featuring a low profile to fit beneath the pubic arch. However, it isn't needed for the left occiput anterior position in this case.

Kiwi Omni cup (Option D) is a disposable handheld vacuum device combining soft and rigid cup features, suitable for various fetal positions but not superior to standard soft cups.

questions.text: A 30 year old primigravida undergoes an assisted vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation due to a prolonged second stage of labour. The obstetrician attempts a vacuum assisted vaginal delivery instead of forceps. Which of the following complications is more likely had the obstetrician used forceps instead of vacuum ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maternal anal sphincter injuries

Explanation:

  • Acute perinatal injuries are more common with vacuum application as compared to forceps application.
  • Maternal perineal injuries are more common with forceps application as compared to vacuum as they occupy more space.

Subgaleal haemorrhage in the neonate (Option A) more common with vacuum delivery, is a severe condition involving bleeding beneath the scalp aponeurosis, though less frequent than cephalohematoma.

Maternal anal sphincter injury (Option B) is more commonly associated with forceps delivery and exacerbated by midline episiotomy

Fetal intracranial haemorrhage (Option D) is serious but rare, can occur with vacuum or forceps delivery, less common than cephalohematoma.

questions.text: A 30 year old nulliparous woman at 41 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. Uterus is term size, relaxed, fetus in cephalic presentation, FHR is 140/min. On per vaginal examination, her cervix is 1 cm dilated and 40% effaced, firm in consistency, midposition and the vertex is at -2 station. What is the most appropriate next step in managing her care?

choices.text: Discuss cervical ripening options before induction.
Shift to the observation unit without further intervention.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Discuss cervical ripening options before induction

Explanation:

This patient’s BISHOP score is 4, which is not favourable for labour induction, so cervical ripening options must be discussed with the patient.

BISHOP Score is Calculated as:

Criteria

0 Points

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Dilation (cm)

Closed

1-2

3-4

≥5

Effacement (%)

0-30

40-50

60-70

≥80

Station

-3

-2

-1, 0

+1, +2

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

  

Position

Posterior

Mid position

Anterior

  
  • Total Score: The sum of points from all five criteria.
  • Interpretation:
    • 6: Unfavorable cervix (cervical ripening agents may be necessary)
    • ≥8: Favorable cervix for induction (high likelihood of successful induction)

Proceed with induction immediately (Option A): With a Bishop score of 4, the cervix is unfavorable, and induction may be less successful without prior cervical ripening.

Schedule a cesarean section (Option B): A Bishop score of 4 indicates an unfavorable cervix but doesn't warrant immediate cesarean; cervical ripening can still aid vaginal delivery.

Shift to the observation unit without further intervention (Option D): Shifting to the observation unit before starting cervical ripening would delay labour further and could lead to the arrest of labour.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman at 39 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with concerns about her pregnancy. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, 70% effaced, soft consistency, and anterior. All of the following are indications for labour induction except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Active genital herpes infection.

Explanation:

In the given scenario (Cervical Cavity is 5 cm dilated = 3, 70% effaced = 2, soft = 2, anterior = 2, so the total score = 9), the BISHOP score is >8, which is favourable for induction. However, Active genital herpes infection is a contraindication for the induction of labor.

Indications for Induction of Labour

Contraindications of Induction of Labour

Maternal

Fetal

  • Membrane rupture without labor (Option A) 
  • Nonreassuring fetal status
  • Gestational hypertension (Option B)
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Oligohydramnios (Option C)
  • Maternal medical conditions such as chronic hypertension and diabetes
  • Abnormally implanted placenta
  • Prior uterine incision with a high rupture risk
  • Active genital herpes infection (Option D)
  • Contracted or distorted pelvic anatomy
  • Cervical cancer
  • Significant macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Malpresentation
  • Nonreassuring fetal status

questions.text: A 28 year old woman at 41 weeks gestation with a history of a previous cesarean section presents to the labour and delivery unit for induction of labour. Which method/medication should be avoided due to her history of a cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Misoprostol

 

Explanation: 

Misoprostol is avoided in patients with a history of cesarean as it shows higher rates of uterine rupture (6 times more patients with uterine rupture with misoprostol than other uterine stimulants used in the induction of labour in patients with a previous cesarean).

Transcervical Foley's catheter (Option C): 

  • A transcervical Foley catheter is a mechanical method for cervical ripening in women with an unfavorable cervix.

  • Lower risk of uterine hyperstimulation compared to prostaglandins.

  • Safe for women with a previous cesarean section.

  • It can be used with intact or ruptured membranes (though less preferred with ruptured).

  • Contraindicated in cases of infection or vaginal bleeding.

Medications Used in Induction of Labour:

Medication

Indication

Side Effects

Oxytocin (Option A)

Induction and augmentation of labour
  • Tachysystole (>5 Uterine contractions in 10 mins)
  • water intoxication (SIADH) → hyponatremia → convulsions

Dinoprostone (Option B)

 

 

 

 

 

 

Cervical ripening and labour induction
  • Tachysystole
  • Remove the vaginal insert if tachysystole is seen.

 

 

Misoprostol (Option D)
  • Not recommended for women with previous cesarean sections.
  • Tachysystole
  • GI upset
  • Uterine rupture in VBAC.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman at 41 weeks gestation comes to the labour and delivery room. On per vaginal examination, her BISHOP score is 9 and uterine contractions every 30 min. Artificial rupture of membranes is planned using the instrument shown in the image below. Which of the following is the instrument being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kocher's forceps

 

Explanation:

  • The patient is undergoing surgical augmentation of labor.

  • Identified by toothed tips: one side has one tooth, the other has two.

  • Designed to grasp fetal membranes.

  • Available in straight or curved forms.

  • Kocher's Forceps have Multiple uses in Obstetrics:

    • Clamping Umbilical Cord
    • Artificial Rupture of Membranes
    • Hemostatic and Pedicle Clamp

 

Allis forceps (Option A): Typically used to grasp tissue like skin or fascia, not suitable for artificial rupture of menbranes 

Simpson forceps (Option B) : 

  • Obstetrical forceps assist in delivering the fetal head during childbirth.

  • Not used for artificial rupture of membranes

Kielland forceps (Option C)​​​​​​: Rotational forceps are used to rotate and deliver the fetal head in assisted vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A 28 year old woman at 41 weeks of gestation is being considered for induction of labour. All of the following are contraindications to induction of labor except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Post-term pregnancy

Explanation:

Post-term pregnancy is an indication of performing Induction of labor.  IOL or initiation of fetal surveillance at 41 weeks gestation is a reasonable option, but most prefer IOL at 41 completed weeks because of studies showing slightly increased risk of stillbirth with expectant management at 41 weeks.

Conditions where vaginal delivery or labor is not possible or not feasible, IOL would be contraindicated. 

  • Contraindications to IOL :
    • Active genital herpes (Option C)
    • Inadequate pelvis
    • Placenta previa(Option A)
    • Previous 2 CS, previous classical CS
    • Cervical cancer
    • Malpresentations
    • Non-reassuring fetal status / Fetal distress(Option D)

questions.text: A 30 year old multipara at 40 + 5 weeks of gestation is scheduled for labour induction. The cervical exam reveals a Bishop score of 5. The device given below is considered for cervical ripening. Which of the following is the correct route of application of this device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intracervical

Explanation:

  • The image in the scenario depicts Laminaria tents, which are hygroscopic dilators inserted and placed intracervically as a part of mechanical induction.
  • Mechanical induction releases endogenous prostaglandins from the membrane and maternal decidua, resulting in the induction of labour and cervical ripening.

Laminaria Tents:

  • Made of dry seaweed with hygroscopic action.

  • Swells in 10–12 hours to dilate the cervix.

  • Rapidly improves Bishop score.

  • Uncomfortable and requires a speculum for insertion.

  • May not shorten induction-to-delivery time with oxytocin

Other Methods of Mechanical Induction of Labour:

  • Single Balloon Foley’s Catheter: inserted transcervically. (Option A)

  • Transcervical Double Balloon Catheter
  • Mechanical Dilator Insertion
  • Extraamniotic Saline Infusion

The transvaginal route (Option C) is used to deliver misoprostol tablets, which are used to chemically ripen the cervix for the induction of labour or medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 26 year old primigravida at 40 weeks of gestation undergoes labour induction with oxytocin. Throughout the induction process, she receives excess intravenous fluid infusion as the resident forgets to monitor the rate of fluid infusion. Which of the following complications will most likely occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Water intoxication

 

Explanation:

Induction of labour with oxytocin requires close monitoring of fluid intake to prevent water intoxication.

  • Unmonitored infusion of excessive hypotonic fluids can lead to dilutional hyponatremia (water intoxication).
  • It results from the antidiuretic action of oxytocin.
  • RL is preferred over dextrose to avoid water intoxication
  • Symptoms include nausea, headache, confusion, and severe neurological symptoms like seizures or coma.
  • Regular monitoring of electrolyte levels is crucial to detect and prevent hyponatremia.
  • Adjusting intravenous fluid rates according to patient response helps manage the risk of water intoxication during labour induction.

Complications of Induction of Labor Depending on the Methods Used:

Method Used

Complication

Oxytocin

  • Water intoxication
  • Uterine rupture / tachysystole (Option C)
  • Hypotension
  • Fetal distress (Option A)

Artificial Rupture of Membrane

  • Cord prolapse
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Bleeding

Sweeping of Membrane
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • PROM (Premature Rupture of membranes)

Misoprostol

  • Tachysystole
  • Meconium-stained liquor (Option D)
  • Uterine rupture
  • Fetal distress

Foley Catheter

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Infections

Mechanical Dilators

Maternal and fetal infections.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida at 38 weeks comes to the OPD with a complaint stating that her Daily Fetal Movement Count (DFMC) is nil. On USG, fetal heart rate is absent. A diagnosis of Intrauterine fetal death was made, and delivery of the fetus was planned. If the cervix is unfavourable, what is the first-line choice agent for induction of labor?

choices.text: 200 mg Oral Mifepristone + 25 μg intravaginal misoprostol (4 hourly)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 200 mg Oral Mifepristone + 25 μg intravaginal misoprostol (4 hourly)

 

Explanation:

Since the cervix is unfavourable, the treatment of choice for the induction of labour in intrauterine death of the fetus (IUDF) is 200 mg Oral Mifepristone + 25 μg intravaginal misoprostol (4 hourly)

Oxytocin infusion (Option A): Oxytocin infusion is used when the cervix is favorable; if unfavorable, cervical ripening is needed, and oxytocin is not good choice.

 

Oral Misoprostol 50 μg (Option C): It is a safe, cheap, and effective method to induce labour in IUFD, But not used as the first choice of management

 

Vaginal PGE2 gel 6 hourly (Option D) is used, but not as first-line management, but when IUFD is there: Misoprostol and mifepristone or even misoprostol alone works better than vaginal PGE2 gel
